children.subject: Which 2 or 3 should I take for my last semester based on my post and your experiences
162 isn't that important for mobile development
Thanks! I've narrowed it down to some subset of 162, 161, 126, 127.

You're going to most likely have a bit of trouble with 189 if you havent taken 16b, 126, 127, or math 110. If you do want to commit to ML I'd suggest taking at least 1-2 of those courses before 189. That being said, if you had to pick 1 course from those that's really important it would prolly be 162. If ur tryna go hard id say 162, 126, 189 or 162 127 189 are good options. Otherwise just take 162 161. 188 can be self studied the easiest (though you definitely wont get the mastery of the material you would get by taking the class, its just that the materials are all there for you), and is not really relevant to ML/DS. 16b on its own is kinda cool but doesn't really give you enough to do anything meaningful. 110 and 134 are ok for 189 but 127 and 126 are way better. maybe data 100?

I'm confident in my work ethic and motivation, and I get good grades, but i'm very slow when I learn new material. As a result, I don't see myself taking 162, 126, 189.

At most i'd take 162, 126, and 127 but that seems too much as well. I'll ask on a follow up post to see what others think with that workload.

Thanks for the advice!

I would definitely not take 189 without at least EE 16B and some review of Math 53 (check out MIT OCW), but if it's your last semester and you really want some ML exposure, take it and see if you can fill in your gaps in knowledge yourself (doable but hard).

Honestly, it's hard to give a good answer because it depends on your work ethic and true motivation to study the subject. Are you doing it to feel out whether AI is something you'd be interested in? You don't need to take a Berkeley course for that (check out Andrew Ng's Coursera course or Udacity's AI courses). If it's to buff your resume or show to employers "yeah I took an AI class," you are better off doing a side project and trying to self-study the material covered in these courses. But otherwise, I say follow Anon's advice and go hard. 162, 126, and 189 is the way to go.
Okay thank you! Looks like i'm at least definitely taking 162, and will consider 188, although I think I will self study it.

Ive taken 6 of the classes you listed and I'd recommend 162 and 188. 188 will give you a great overview of AI without needing the math background for 189 and I think 162 is a class that every CS major should take.

Thank you. I'm leaning heavily towards 161 and 162. I will study ML at my own pace after graduation, whether that's starting from simple statistics and linear algebra books/courses, to self studying the UC Berkeley EECS and ML courses.

I'd definitely recommend that 161 be one of the 2 or 3 classes you take. Even if you do not plan on becoming a security engineer, the concepts and practices you learn in 161 are extremely beneficial.

I truly believe that 161 was the class that most made me a better programmer. After learning how easy it is to exploit carelessly written code, you start to think about all the code you write from the perspective of how secure it is against attack, which is useful regardless of what field you go into.

history.content:
Which 2(or 3) should I take? I only need 2 to graduate.

Options:

General Software Engineering: CS 161, CS 162

AI/ML: EE 16B, Stat 134, Math 110, EECS 126, EECS 127, CS 188, CS 189

I'm going into the industry as a Mobile developer but may switch into ML/DS. With that being said, I don't want to get a Masters so if I were to become an ML person, it'd be through self studying or taking online courses. I definitely believe taking EECS 126 and EECS 127 will be a great stepping stone to actually start self studying ML. Unfortunately, i'm not prepared to take those courses with only CS 70(during a summer, 2 weeks of material) being my experience. My two worst math subjects are Linear Algebra and Stats.

I also have a choice to take 2 or 3 courses. I think 2 is a good balance and i'll probably join a few CS clubs.
